data.title: Improve tab visualization
data.body:
I'd like to add the possibility for the user to choose three characters for tab visualization. Here's the first assumption: a tab is defined by the column it ends at, not the column is starts at. See this example for Notepad++:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12711504/12964971/3c714bba-d053-11e5-9613-9a4d942baaa5.png)

The idea would be to specify two characters:
1. The first character is there to 'fill the gaps'
2. The second character is necessarily put at the end.

Thus, if the tab is 5 characters long and you set the two characters to '-' and '>' respectively, it would display as '---->'. If the tab is only one character long, it would display as '>'

data.title: Let packages define deserializers & view providers as main module methods
Allow Users to Consent to Metrics Data Collection Before Collecting Data
data.body: The only thing holding me back from using this editor is the creepy data collection which is not even made clear to the user. I would have no problem with it if Atom didn't send any usage statistics until the user consented to the data collection.

data.title: Add config option to disable the concept of "pending tabs"
data.body:
After updating to atom 1.6.0-beta0, I found that my usual habit of opening tabs through single clicking was disrupted by having the tabs replace each other instead of opening next to each other.

I had to dig in to the release notes to find the problem - I was automatically opted in to the feature of "pending tabs", with no way out.  I never want to see a tab in a "pending" state, ever.  There should be a way to turn this feature off, and return to the previous behavior, in which every tab is always "non-pending".  A checkbox in the settings should be sufficient for this.

data.title: After update, Atom crashes on start (segfault)
data.body:

I just upgraded my atom to the latest git master. Please don't ask me what version I was using before... ;) I'm running Gentoo Linux.

data.title: Destroying atom by launching Setup again
data.body:
I successfully installed Atom a few weeks ago.

Today I accidently started the AtomSetup.exe (the installer) again. As expected, it failed. But after that nothing worked no more. I tried uninstalling, it just happend, but the uninstaller misses a lot (remove registry entries etc.).

Additionaly, the log shows stuff that is not right, I know which folders I deleted( `Install path C:\Users\inetphantom\AppData\Local\atom already exists, burning it to the ground` )

After that, Atom (out of `\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.4.0\lib\net45`) worked, but not the Update.exe from Squirrel. 

[SquirrelSetup.log](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/124944/SquirrelSetup.log.txt) (Uninstall)
[SquirrelSetup.log](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/124869/SquirrelSetup.log.txt)(AtomSetup.exe)
[SquirrelSetup.log](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/124863/SquirrelSetup.log.txt) (Update.exe)

I would wish me a Atom-remover beside the uninstaller, and that the installer should not break the working installation

data.title: Git status is cleared when switching windows
data.body:
Hello, first of:
OS: Linux Mint 17.3 Cinnamon Edition (based on Ubuntu 14.04)
WM: Awesome v3.4.15
Atom: Stable 1.5.0
Git: 2.7.1

When I'm editing a file in my project using git the colour on the file in tree-view changes to orange (or what-ever-it-is). But when I switch to another screen/window and go back the whole tree changes to the "nothing changed state" even when git status reports changes in the files. This did not happen in Atom 1.4.0 and was the reason for me changing to 1.4.0 from 1.5.0-beta3.

Reproduced while running safe mode in both 1.5.0 and 1.6.0-beta0.

If you need any more information, please let me know.

data.title: Files are opened on same tab instead creating a new one
data.body:
Not sure if this is a new feature in 1.6.0 ...

![tabs](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11627131/12946136/860468fe-cff2-11e5-8eaa-61b15ee7e645.gif)

When I click on a file atom opens the tab, but when I click on another file it will be opened on the same tab. It looks like I have to double-click to "lock in" a certain file.

OSX 10.11.3
Atom 1.6.0-beta0 (Didn't notice it in any of the previous versions)

data.title: Using the Close Tab command on an 'empty' window will close the window itself.
data.body:
When closing multiple tab using the CTRL+W command (Windows) I tend to hold down the button. Recently noticed that doing this no longer leaves and empty atom client/window open, the one where the tips cycle in the backdrop. I believe that it used to be so that if all the tabs where closed the command would not perform any action, which I prefer. If I'd wanted to close the whole window I'd use the proper command, in this case CTRL+SHIFT+W. 

This seems like a simple fix/hack for someone with insight of the source code. It also would help by preventing unwanted behavior for task specific commands such as this.

I'm using Atom 1.5 on Windows 7 if that helps.

data.title: Moved/renamed files (via tree view) with open tabs not linked anymore after operation
data.body:
If I have a file open in Atom that I want to rename/move, and use tree view to do this, the tabs of the files lose track of where the file source is, and continuing to edit in the file tab causes the old file to be re-created on save.

Is it possible to have tree view inform the tab package of the file rename/move somehow, so that the source of the tab is updated and we can keep editing the file?

Having to close the tab and reopen it for the new file seems a bit 1990's :)

Possibly related: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/9875
Although I would not propose to close the file buffers, just point them to the right folder/files again.

Maybe this is not something that's normal/common in Windows apps, but on Mac it's pretty common. Any file that I'm editing, I can just move it around or rename it freely, and any app using the file will still have a pointer to the correct file location.

data.title: Blue notifications "close all" button does not work
data.body:
I use a plug-in which displays blue notifications at the top right on occasion. The notifications have a "close all" button, but the button doesn't do anything. The "close all" button on red notifications works fine though. I hope this is enough information; I'm not sure if there's anything unique about the plugin's notifications.

Original issue: https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-flow/issues/46

data.title: Add link to article on glob patterns
data.body:
Ultimately we should add some stuff to the Flight Manual about file globs in various places in Atom. I just wanted to get something in place for now because of:

https://discuss.atom.io/t/tree-view-not-ignoring-ignored-names-names/25258

data.title: Clarify Windows build docs for VS2015 etc.
All files in Tree marked as New(Green)
data.body:
I just updated to Atom 1.5 and now when opening any folder within a local repo each file in the tree is marked as green (marked as a new file). If I click and open the file it un-marks it green and goes back to clean. Note: The files are marked as green but Git doesn't pick them up as new files so I can still work with the files per normal.

I ran in Safe mode and was still able to reproduce the bug. I also tried different UI and Syntax themes and it still occurs.

I did notice that if I open the project from the root of the repo it works as intended, and the issue only seems present when opening a folder deeper within the repo.
#### Tree in root Git project

![root](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/419370/12931270/81d1bd14-cf42-11e5-8bbf-a055d96a4cd1.png)
#### Tree in sub dir of same project (files in screenshot are **NOT** new)

![subdir](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/419370/12931298/aaf6f114-cf42-11e5-9592-641f13b8cbcd.png)

data.title: Atom doesn't update Tab Type after "Convert Spaces To Tabs"
data.body: After converting a file from space-based indentation to tab-based indentation (or vice versa), Atom continues to insert spaces (or tabs) for newlines or tab-keypresses.

data.title: Cmd + shift + z does not work on Dvorak keyboards (cmd + y does)
data.body:
**Steps:**

Normal (US) keyboard:
- set keyboard layout to **US**
- start `atom --safe`
- new file
- type something
- `cmd + z` undoes
- `cmd + shift + z` redoes 

Dvorak keyboard:
- set keyboard layout to **Dvorak**
- start `atom --safe`
- new file
- type something
- `cmd + z` undoes
- `cmd + shift + z` **does not redo**
- `cmd + y` does redo

**Notes:**
- Running `1.4.3` on `El Capitan`
- I've had this problem since I started using Atom, two days ago
- This is first and only keybinding issue I've ever encountered in using Dvorak for the last 6 years on Mac.

Anything I can do to provide more info?

data.title: Don't cascade on reload
data.body:
Fixes #10648.

So this fix is a little fussy.
1. Ideally we’d simply update the window load settings with the window dimensions before we reload, so that the reloaded window has the same dimensions.
2. **But** any changes we make to the window load settings in our `beforeunload` handler aren’t reflected in the reload. (I suspect Chromium’s grabbing the location for reload before calling the handler?)
3. So the next best thing: we detect a reload before `beforeunload` is called and update the window load settings there. This worked for _most_ reloads but I wasn’t able to find a hook for reloads triggered by cmd-r with the dev tools focused. That inconsistency would have been super annoying, to me at least.
4. So instead we track whether this is the first time the window’s been loaded. If it is, we use the default dimensions. If it isn’t, we use the dimensions we’re already saving in state.

@atom/core I’m curious if I’ve totally overcomplicated this or missed anything obvious.

data.title: Tooltips on tabs show at incorrect times.
data.body: If you command+tab switch to Atom from another application, and your mouse just happens to be on top of a tab (GUI Tab at the top of the screen), then the tooltip appears showing the file name. This should not be the case. The tooltip should only show if you explicitly moved your mouse onto the tab (or in the tab) and stopped moving on the tab.

data.title: Setting a keybinding to the empty string silently invalidates all the following entries
data.body:
If in keymap.cson a keystroke is set to the empty string (`''`), the entire file from there on is ignored.
I'd expect Atom to raise an error/warning and save some headaches.

I'm experiencing this problem on Atom 1.4.3 on Windows 10. [This Atom Discuss topic](https://discuss.atom.io/t/cant-override-f2-keybinding/25077/7) features the same problem.

Here's a problematic keymap.cson file

``` cson
'atom-text-editor':
    'f2': 'refactor:rename'

'body':
    'ctrl-shift-S': 'window:save-all'
    'alt-1': ''
    'alt-2': 'unset!'

'.platform-win32 atom-workspace':
    'ctrl-alt-shift-T': 'unset!'
    'ctrl-shift-C': 'open-terminal-here:open'
```

`ctrl-shift-S` will work, but `ctrl-shift-C` won't.

![atom-bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5738009/12910238/0dbaf9a6-cf09-11e5-8abc-289e268472cb.gif)

data.title: Add MRU tab switching functionality
data.body:
Fixes #5344 

First thing I did was give the `Pane` class an `itemStack` property to keep track of the order the items were used. The main function I added is `activateNextRecentlyUsedItem` which walks down the `itemStack` each time the user hits tab after ctrl is held down.

I set up the keymap for ctrl-tab but I still don't have the keymaps figured out for when ctrl is held down and tab is pressed over and over before lifting up on ctrl.  Something else I need to figure out is how to call a specific function to move an item to the top of the stack once ctrl is lifted.  

So, based on the assumption that I can make a keymap for holding down ctrl and pressing tab over and over (suggestions are welcome), I set up my code so that `activateNextRecentlyUsedItem` would be called each time the user hits tab when holding down ctrl.  Each call to this function would walk down the `itemStack`.  When the user lifted the ctrl key, somehow we would need to call `moveItemToTopOfStack` which would move the item the user stopped on to the top of the stack.

I modified the serialization, too, so the `itemStack` would persist.  The 4 scenarios I was focusing on are:
- nothing is wrong
- no `itemStack` serialized
- some items not serialized
- for some reason there is a different number of items in the `itemStack` than in the `items` array

I wrote tests for the MRU functionality and for the different serialization scenarios.

So yeah, this won't work correctly until I can figure out the key maps for holding ctrl down and hitting tab more than once and until I can figure out how to call `moveItemToTopOfStack` when ctrl is lifted.

data.title: Tabs to Spaces screws up middle indentation
data.body:
Consider this line, in Atom 1.4.3 with a tabLength of 8:

``` lisp
(E100_C     (dP -0.1)   (dT 100))
```

Using the Tabs to Spaces command should produce 9 spaces for the two consecutive tabs. However, Atom produces 16 spaces, pretending the line isn't indented in the middle. The choice of 8 is unimportant: Atom incorrectly converts tabs to spaces for all tabLengths.
